review_title: HR is not responsible for the mistake they make
pros: NA NA NA NA NA
cons:
From 2019 to 2022, I was an employee at Boys Town National Research Hospital (BTNRH), Omaha, NE. When I was about to terminate this job, I received a COBRA packet from the HR department of BTNRH. This packet included information about how to extend medical insurance after leaving the job. It did not include any information about how to handle the money in my FSA account. It was indeed a mistake made by HR and HR later admitted it. This mistake was very misleading to me. Because of it, I thought I could use my medical FSA money for the entire year of 2022 without any issues. I did not realize it was not the case until very late. 
As a result, I lost all my FSA money. If I knew the policy before I left the job, I would spend the FSA money in a timely manner so that I would not lose it. BTNRH did not fulfill the obligation to deliver important information to the employee who was about to leave the job. I believe BTNRH has to be responsible for my loss. However, BTNRH disappointed me. Although I contacted the leaders of BTNRH, they ignored my emails. So far no one from BTNRH has said sorry to me either. 
For all the potential employees and current employees, I hope you can read my message here and I also hope this message can warn you when you make the decision about the choice of job.

job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Omaha, NE
pros: The company really does a great job of introducing the company culture and developing their employees from the moment they arrive. I have never been through a more thorough orientation, training, and onboarding experience. Also, the staff I worked with
cons:
The pay for many positions is quite horrible. The level of input and influence that entry level employees have with treatment was also frustrating. Technicians spend more time with youth in IRTC and STGH than any professional. However, we were not asked to provide recommendations or information beyond generic case notes. Tech positions are a turn and burn position and as a result I was never known as anything but "Staff" from the educators, therapists, and Sr. Leaders. The pay was poor, but not having a name was degrading. 

Growth is also a concern here. There is not a clear career path to move up in the organization. Tech I, II, and III were the best you could hope for. 

Lastly, you have a great model. However, there is more than one milieu to consult and implement. One size does not fit all. Kids come in the door and adapt to Boys Town. Unfortunately, they are not always given the skills they need to survive in an environment that is outside of Boys Town.

review_title: Working at Boys Town is very demanding, but the rewards are worth it!
job_title: Assistant Family Teacher in Boys Town, NE
pros: Boys Town as a whole is very focused by it's mission.  Almost all of the staff I encountered while working there all wanted to help Children and Families become successful.  Boys Town makes sure to support it's employees, especially those working in direct-care positions, with very comprehensive training, 24/7 consultation services, performance feedback and development opportunities.  Boys Town promotes from within often, so there are many avenues one can pursue for advancement.   Benefits package was very competitive and included very affordable healthcare, paid holidays, sick leave, generous vacation time accural, 401k matching, employee assistance, and more.
cons: Challenges included learning how to balance career with personal life as your position can require lots of long hours at all hours of the day, sometimes 7 days a week.  Although job can be rewarding, it is very challenging.  One has to get used to the amount of feedback every staff receives on a regular basis.  Some supervisors and/or directors have a lot of great program knowledge, but are not great at working with and developing staff.   Lots of required meetings and trainings that can take away a lot of personal time.

pros:
Caring for children with traumatic pasts
Faith Based
Salary + Living Expenses are covered as Family Teachers
Watching children progress overtime
Having a budget to do fun things with the kids, because they deserve it! :)
cons:
Family Teachers are not given the appreciation or respect they deserve

Lack of time off is a real issue! Only two 8 hour periods of time off twice a week, and after briefing it is more like 7. 
The children can have serious behavioral issues that can challenge your patience, especially when you have your own child or baby that you need to protect. And especially when you're overtired from not having enough time off.
People are always telling you to do something different, and then when you try what they say and it fails, they treat you as if you came up with the idea, and then give feedback to you as if you were wrong.

review_title: I loved and hated it...GREAT pay...but bad management.
pros: Great benefits to working on main campus! Great paid training. Some pretty good people to work with. Not all, but some. Some of the children will really make all the struggles worth it.
cons: Unorganized upper management. I was told by a construction worker that the house I worked (and lived in) was being cleared of asbestos in an upcoming renovation. It was a BIG reason why we resigned. You aren't allowed to talk to other Family Teachers...you have to also watch your back about what you say. For a huge campus your words will come back to haunt you.

job_title: Police Officer in Boys Town, NE
pros: Some officers are great and a pleasure to work with.
cons: Incompetent Police Administration. You are expected to violate the law, and your oath to apprehend children. You're told the "home" and the "village" are separate but in reality, they are not. Security guards that have arrest authority, and frequently misuse it.

review_title: Non-profits often have problems, but this ones better than most.
pros:
I've worked for  a half-dozen social service/non-profits and Boys Town has some of the most sincere and genuine staff I've had the pleasure to . For non-profit work their compensation is ample, with matching percentages for retirement plans,  good vacation time (which only gets better the longer you work for them), and insurance options.

In general, management is very supportive and desires the best for their employees and the communities we serve.
cons:
My major griefs are the frequency of meetings (which often require coming in on days off for shift workers), the initial lack of sick leave, and that the job is both demanding and occasionally tedious (though that would not be different working for any other company).

Additionally, while not technically Catholic, a lot of their policies reflect specifically Catholic beliefs (the health insurance doesn't cover birth control).

review_title: I had three different directors, and all were the same.
pros: The youth, benefits from the start.
cons: Management management management.  I'm not a disgruntled employee who was fired and just complaining to complain.  I am a current employee going on three years who has done well within the organization.  I stay for the kids and the experience.  Directors and managers are beyond rigid.  The entire model revolves around positive reinforcement, empathy and praise.  The two programs I've worked in couldn't be worse about those three things.  The model isn't made to be rigid; it only works if each employee is allowed to be themselves while teaching, verses being a robot that the kids don't respect.  Problem is, management is never there to actually observe...they rely on looking at your teaching interactions on paper and go off ratios.  They have absolutely no skills when it comes to using positive reinforcement with their employees either.  They only give feedback when it's something you're doing wrong.  I'll stop here because I could go forever...oh and pay is NOT GOOD.

pros: Boys Town is effective.  Every day youth get better and families stay together due to the work of Boys Town employees.  More of a mission than a job, working at Boys Town gives one the sense of accomplishing good every day they go to work.  The support from supervisors is tremendous and expected (part of the culture).  While the direct care work is demanding, it is at the same time immensely rewarding.  The training provided is thorough.  The Mission pervades every decision.  How do we know we make a difference?  WE ASK.  Families and youth consistently rate the quality of care they receive very highly.  Those who do not truly love and care for hurting children and families should not apply.  Those that do, you won't find a better, more professional organization in which to serve.
cons: Mandates from outside agencies to comply with regulations related to forms and paperwork remove people from doing the better work of helping children and families.

review_title: Use Your Talents to Make a Difference!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Boys Town, NE
pros: Boys Town is a wonderful organization that is positively impacting the lives of youth and families across the nation each and every day! It is refreshing to work in a positive environment where everyone truly believes in the mission of the organization and is here to make a difference in someone else's life! It's rewarding to be able to use your own gifts and give back to your community!
cons: Employees at times may not put enough attention on their own personal health and needs because they are so driven by their desire to help others. It is important to continually encourage employees to have appropriate work/life balance. Help them understand this will make them more efficient and effective on the job, so they can continually perform to the high standards expected when delivering top services to our communities.

review_title: Getting paid to make the world a better place!
pros: Mission is at the heart of everything we do in Youth Care and Health Care.  Our Youth Care programs are evidence and research based and have been replicated in a variety of diverse communities across the Country with fantastic outcomes for children and families!  Great benefits, opportunities for relocation, good pay, fabulous development opportunities, long, storied organizational history and stable employment.
cons: Boys Town is a very established, large, and spread out organization making change frequently slow.  Employees love Boys Town, so they never leave, limiting upward mobility, especially if you are limited to one location.  People who don't love it, leave quickly.  It is a very conservative organization where diversity of thinking, experience, culture, etc. is only now starting to be considered a good thing.  But, progress is happening.

pros: Excellent morale, staff very mission oriented, staff development outstanding, large enough locally and nationally to have career ladders for staff.  The quality of programs are outstanding and the dedication to program research and development keeps the organization on the cutting edge.  High levels of staff competency not only serves the mission, but also helps staff succeed within the organization as well as with other orgs if they leave.
cons: Because the Boys Town culture is so strong, only strong and talented staff from outside have an easy time breaking through.   Boys Town is large enough to do things it's own way and needs to collaborate better with others.

pros: None at all. I would not recommend this job to anyone.
cons: You basically work 24/7 with only 8hrs off twice per week, constant abuse from violent teenagers, and lack of sleep since you live in the home with these demons. Boys town has a motto that there are no bad kids, only parents, well that’s how they treat their employees as well. When the kids are at school they keep you busy with a plethora of meetings. I thought this place was all about helping kids and we were very ambitious at the start, but were basically forced out because our assistant was older than us and he had issues with this (he left first but we were sour after it all.) If anything happens in the home with the kids, they look at it like what did you do to provoke this? We decided to give it another shot at a different location, but the fact that they had a high turnover rate should have been a red flag. This site was even worse so no wonder boys town shut them down. Our supervisor would talk to our kids in private to persuade them not to file any charges or complaints if something happened with another kid. We left soon after that.

review_title: Great company with lots of opportunity for advancement
job_title: Youth Care Worker At Emergency Shelter
pros:
- Good pay and great benefits
- Excellent training and continued education
- They promote from within and offer tuition reimbursement
- The Boys Town Model really works for a lot of kids and you can see lives transformed
- 4 day work week
cons:
- Highly stressful work environment (working with teens from very troubled backgrounds)
- Supervisors do not respect your days off, as they are constantly calling for you to work extra hours
- Sometimes expected to work extra long shifts (15 hours) without overtime pay.  They will "rearrange" hours in order to avoid you going over 40 in a week... even though you did!
- Required to work holidays
- You can't get time off unless you find someone to cover your shift because it's a 24/7 facility.

review_title: Awful management and hostile work environment.
job_title: Family Teacher in Boys Town, NE
pros: There is  some opportunity to help kids make progress. Staff gain experience in coping with extreme stress and political agendas. Staff also learn to work independently with little or no support. They also work hard to provide their contract employees  with a large amount of contradictory  and confusing information, which also adds to the experience.
cons: Some of the challenges of working at Boys Town are that  physical violence against the staff is permitted, and kids are often not held accountable for their poor actions. Often there is a double standard for boys and girls. How the children are treated depends largely on that child's source of funding, and if they are a top athlete. Clairifying questions intended to help an employee understand how to improve are a sure way to get disciplinary action because it is considered "not accepting feedback/decisions". A  Request from HR to contact the company directly to express concerns is a trap, and should be avoided at all cost, because administration and HR are vindictive.

review_title: Value the employees doing the work
pros: If you care about kids, this is the job for you.
cons: Management has an attitude that they know best, when they don't participate in any of the teaching and care giving-ever.  They don't seem to value the peons at the bottom, don't ask our advice, and don't realize that we put our heart and soul into these kids.  It's really not just a job, but an all-encompassing, all-consuming 5 am to midnight endeavor to feed, clothe, teach, and manage a house of 6 kids...and then do the paperwork to document that it is done.

pros: Boys Town offers challenging work, but it is extremely rewarding and worth every minute. I am excited to come to work every day as my coworkers have always been welcoming, and my leadership provides me the king of positive feedback that shows they value the work I do and want me to succeed. One unique part about this organization is that they encourage you to expand your network outside your department, and leadership is open and excited to get involved with events around campus whether it is volunteer events with the youth or even a networking event with the Emerging Leaders Professional Development group.
cons: Boys Town has taken great strides to stay current not only within the industry, but as a national organization. If Boys Town keeps on working towards on bettering itself both for our mission and our employees I see no cons.

review_title: Research Assistant... poor pay, expensive part-time benefits.
pros: good human resources department, good ethics & values as a company. nursing department seems like the best department to be in.
cons: Very expensive benefits if part-time and poor pay compared to other institutions. Poor guidance and leadership by my particular Research Associate. No management skills and lack of knowledge hospital policies, but my "manager" only managed one or two employees.  Bottom of the totem pole feeling and no gratitude from supervisor. Not a high paying job and hard to be self-motivated for an ungrateful boss whom you do so much work for.

pros: Touching the lives of the youth, coworkers, and good learning experience.  Benefits right off the start.  Orientation was very thorough.
cons: Pay, little opportunity for growth, management is rigid and encouraged punitive teaching.  Experience very dependent on home you were placed in.

review_title: No matter the position you have, you are a part of a mission of caring for kids and families.
job_title: Youth Care Business/Compliance in Omaha, NE
pros: I have worked for this organization for over 30 years.  I have seen it expand is services and work force to 11 different locations across the United States.  Each location has opportunities for upward mobility.  There is even greater opportunities if you are willing to relocate through out your career.  The training that you receive to be successful in your job is outstanding.
cons: Due to working with children and families, not all work is done during the hours of  9-5 Monday through Friday.  You will learn life/work balance.  The rewards of seeing a child or family make progress and keep the family intact makes the extra effort worth it.

review_title: Helping Youth and Families is my passion.
pros: The work is challenging but very rewarding. Full benefits at hire. Lots of support from supervisors and many opportunities for growth including on-going training, educational scholarships, and educational reimbursement.
cons: It's hard to keep things balanced some days. We work with kids and their needs don't always occur between 8 and 5. Some days are long, but it's the effort that makes things so rewarding. We get to see the kids and their families change and become better prepared for life outside of Boys Town. Working at Boys Town isn't for everyone. You must learn have a heart for helping others, be able to manage yourself in some stressful situations, and be wiling to put in the long hours which are sometimes required.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Boys Town, NE
pros:
Every day when I come to work I feel good about what I do. I don't work directly with the youth but I know that I am making a difference in children's life. Boys Town's Mission is about changing the way America cares for children and families by providing and promoting a continuum of care that strengthens body, mind and spirit.
I truly love my job!
cons: I don't have any. Boys Town is a non-profit and the wages reflect that.

pros: I gained great clinical experience while employed here. Boys Town has been around for many years and is a well developed national organization. They have plenty of resources and are known for paying their employees well, especially for social service jobs.
cons: Boys Town's headquarters are in Nebraska and sometimes there was a big disconnect from the New York location compared to the rest of the locations across the nation. Being the largest, most diverse city in the country, the New York location faced unique challenges and barriers that it seemed the rest of the organization did not recognize. Though their model has been proven to work for most youth, not having a campus along with other factors made this not as efficient in NY and there needed to be more support.

review_title: Boys Town is a remarkable organization to work for
pros: Though helping troubled youth and families can be a challenging task, working for an organization that makes all of its decisions based on the best interest of those kids and families is unbelievably meaningful and rewarding.  Boys Town is unique in their dedication to training, consultation, and evaluation so that those working directly with kids and families have the education and support necessary to help them be successful.  Boys Town is also a national organization with opportunities for career advancement in its eleven Sites across the country.  I couldn't ask for a better employer or more dedicated and supportive co-workers.
cons: Boys Town sets high standards for quality.  Potential employees must understand and embrace the high expectations that accompany any jobs working with Boys Town kids and families.

review_title: Making a difference in the lives of youth and families is it's own reward
pros:
Working with the kids and seeing the change in them for the better is extremely rewarding.  Even in a support position, where you don't work directly with youth or families, all you have to do is go to a  home for dinner or attend a function the youth are having and you can see the difference. 
There is training and support for every department.  The training for direct care staff is motivating and prepares new employees for their positions.
Majority of the employees are here for the Mission and it shows.  
Excellent benefits and opportunity for growth & development.
cons: Being non-profit, the salary ranges tend to be a little lower than for-profit organizations.

job_title: Family Teacher in Boys Town, NE
pros: Get to work with kids who really need the help you provide. Good co worker relations. A sense of purpose when you go to work.
cons: Management doesn't care about their staff. When given feedback and you ask a question, you are told you are hard to work with and don't accept feedback well. Management will flip flop on issues going on and will always find a reason they are not wrong, and it is your fault because you aren't doing it right, even though it is how they told you.

pros: This is the front lines for trying to help troubled youth. If you like mission work, this is the place.
cons: Top level administration cares little if at all for in home staff. If you are an FT/AFT you can easily see decisions are made based on the almighty dollar for the company, with little concern for how those decisions affect staff or actually help the youth.

pros: Boys Town focuses on developing and enhancing strategies to improve services to children and families. Ongoing efforts to solicit feedback as often as they could, especially from direct consumers to determine what works and what needs to get better is always at the fore front when it comes to quality improvement.
cons: Funding for programs is a constant challenge. Contracts with state agencies drive work away from the core values by emphasizing compliance with paperwork. Also, as an agency we are behind with regards to technology as the work force becomes increasingly reliant on mobile systems.

review_title: Working with and developing the future youth of America into successful citizens was a satisfying experience.
job_title: Youth Care Worker in Omaha, NE
pros:
The chance to change the lives of Americas youth for the better. 
Working with other individuals who are like minded.
Seeing the success in youth that have left the program and knowing you had a part in that transformation.
cons:
No respect from the youth. Some extreme examples are yelling, throwing of objects, swearing, in your face spitting marathons. 

Organization wise, it is my opinion that the focus is now primarily about money and less about the youth of America. 

Administration/general lack of support

review_title: I have worked for Boys Town for almost 10 years.
pros: The company believes in their mission from the top to the bottom.  They truly believe in changing the way america cares for children and families.  They have a lot of research to support their model of care.  The compensation is competitive and the benefits are excellent.
cons: They are always wanting more and not considerate of your personal life and health.  The management recognizes the negative behavior, but does not use positive reinforcement.  They have no sense of the amount of stress and emotionally draining working with youth 24/7 does.

review_title: Best Company I've ever worked for
pros: Comprehensive paid training. Many opportunities for feedback and personal development. Intensive but paid training immediately after hire. You will meet many training staff with longevity well beyond 15 to 20 years.
cons: Mandatory 2 week training in Omaha. I don't really consider this a con, however, I could see this being a difficulty for someone with children. The training is paid and well worth the travel.

pros:
Excellent benefits - best health care coverage you'll ever have!

Easy to manage work-life balance

Good discount program available to employees at stores and restaurants
cons:
HR is either unwilling or unable to help you when you have legitimate concerns about a supervisor - especially someone higher level. I was not the only person who complained to HR, either. If you end up with an unethical boss who creates a hostile work environment, you might as well just leave your job because HR won't help you. 

Lower-than-average salary

No room for growth/advancement

Poor upper management

pros: The mission statement, if they were to uphold it.  Working with children in need.  Sense of friendship within immediate co-worker team.  Great pay with outstanding benefits that are unmatched by any company I've ever seen.
cons: "old boy network" mentality.  Upper management don't appreciate talent and they punish individuality and intelligence.  Too many unnecessary middle managers.  All managers came to their positions by manipulation and earning "boys town" degrees that aren't valid any place other than boys town.

pros: Loved the job. Challenging, but could be fun and encouraging. Great team dynamics - but this depends from shift to shift and on location. For me, it was a great experience working with an awesome team. Plenty of opportunities for over time, if you are willing to put in the hours, the paychecks are great. Incredible benefits package.
cons: Frustrations in lack of communication or involvement in multiple levels of management. Got to be a bigger problem after I left, and the problems had compounded, I know.

review_title: A great foundation for my career!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Ana, CA
pros: They are changing the way America cares for their youth, families, and communities beginning with me. They take the time to develop me in my current position. They take the time to ask me if I aspire to become anything else within the agency. They take the time to prepare me to take on higher positions by providing me opportunities to learn about other positions. There is a possibility of moving up within the agency.
cons: If you are not passionate about helping youth, families and communities you are most likely not going to fit in with the demands of fulfilling the shared mission.

review_title: Helping kids and staff learn best practices.
job_title: Family Home Consultant in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Great benefits, flexible job, mostly good people you will work with. Company has lasted over 100 years. You see positive change in kids and families. Very organized and support driven. Tones of development.
cons: Don't pay worth unless you stick around over 10 years. High stress, work home life is not good. On-call and off work every 14 days. Management is a bit clucky but mostly normal. Funding, funding, funding is getting low and government does not help with contracts for decent balance. You won't get rich.

review_title: Keep your mouth shut, and do what you're told; an opinion that differs means you're a troublemaker and not a team player
pros: Flexible Hours and excellent benefits.
cons:
Extremely limited room for advancement within the company. Nepotism at it's worst. 
Extremely limited room for personal growth. Ideas and opinions are not welcome from anyone not in an administrative role. 
Pay is marginal, and all wage increases are limited to a annual 2.5% raise.

review_title: Only if you need a check
pros: Plenty of parking, company card to cover expenses so you don't have to wait to be reimbursed
cons:
Management relies heavily on personal opinion and "gut feelings" when dealing with the lives of disadvantaged youth. Objectivity is extremely lacking. The company emphasizes "accepting feedback" however when ethics concerns arise around service provision you’re more likely to be ostracized and reprimanded for pointing this out. While I come qualified with education and experience to work in the human service field this is not necessary for a position here. Boys Town emphasizes their 2 week crash course that you must attend in Omaha, Nebraska where they will attempt to cram the treatment model. (During my training one of the instructors thought it was okay to tell a story about an African-American male teaching to a youth about why it was not okay to use a well-known racial slur while she herself used the racial slur. I still do not know why this person thought that this was okay.  Also, when reviewing the benefits for the position in Nebraska we were told that it was cheaper for women to have a baby rather than be covered for birth control. Two statements lacking sensitivity/cultural-sensitivity delivered to a room of new-hires.)  The biggest issue that arises, if you choose to work here, is that you quickly learn that their CBT approach does nothing to address the systemic issues that the clients they choose to serve face especially in the District of Columbia.  The company is data driven instead of client centered. Their primary concern is that certain assessments are in the system within "x" amount of days and not whether or not realistic goals are set. This basically means that you just have to put anything in there so that their numbers are where they want them to be. Meeting the person where they are completely goes against the model. The program requires out of home placement for at least a year for the youth to generalize the teachings however they attempt to jam this in within 60 to 120 days.  A service MUST be put into the youth's life within 14 days of admittance whether or not they come in with services or if they're even necessary. There is no consideration for the environmental factors that confront the youth and their families. The belief that you have to throw a “service” or a "resource" at an issue will produce lasting results is rampant. It’s a cookie cutter model.
Other issues arose around a lack of on-site training and supervision. While you are supposed to meet with your supervisor weekly to continue learning the model I did not. Upon my arrival my supervisor repeatedly told me that they did not know what they were doing and they started learning the position when I did. In 6 months I can count on 1 hand the number of times that I met with my supervisor to learn anything. You’re completely on your own if you choose to come here is my only take-away and the sad thing is that the 3 people over you aren’t doing anything themselves. You can attempt to go to them for answers but none of them can agree or no one wants to be the one to give you the wrong answer. The leadership staff is not supportive and show little sign that they communicate on all levels. Within 2 weeks of my start date at my location I reached out to HR to speak with someone about my concerns and did not receive any aid. I would reach out several times over 6 months and even filed an ethics review complaint with the national headquarters for any kind of support for the several incidences that arose ni my time on campus. Instead of support I was lambasted for what had not been done (despite the fact that I had been reaching out over the course of 6 months for any kind of help all the way up to the highest on site office.). This site does not care about new hires especially not if you are knowledgeable in your field. The majority of the campus in the main office has been there well over 6 years and some in the double digits. They “can do no wrong” and they protect each other accordingly. The persons holdiong leadership positions in the company most likely began their career in human services at Boys Town and only know the Boys Town Model and not what the youth of the city actually face. They’re constantly trying to place a square peg into a round hole. If you choose to come to Boys Town it should only be because you’re fresh out of school and have no experience outside of internships and you need experience working with children. It is not a place for long term growth especially if you are an MSW, MFT, LPC or anything of the sort. Get your year in and GO!

pros: This organization allows you to move up through the ranks at a fast pace.
cons: Management plays favoritism. Management know little about the organization they are leading. Taking a sick day is like incurring the wrath of the Devil. Even if you have over a hundred hours saved you are still not allowed to take them. Manager is a gossip and your personal business will end up the topic of an inefficient staff meeting disguised as a general topic. Managers also takes personal supervision meetings to gossip or speak about themselves.

pros: The work that Boys Town does for the youth is amazing! I do not work directly with the youth but they are why I am here. I love working for a bigger reason. My team is supportive and consistently challenges me to think outside the box. Additionally, my manager is supportive and pushes me to grow on a daily basis.
cons: We need to have more family friendly events for staff. We have some however it is usually on a weekend. Yesterday we invited staff's children to come and trick-or-treat at the office. It was such a fun event and it was great to see staff and their families.

review_title: Have been able to help children and families while developing my Human Services career.
pros: Boys Town is a positive environment that has a mission to help children and families.  Boys Town has excellent benefits.
cons: The rate of salary increase every year is very low.  Often times caseloads are high which impacts quality to families and ability to do well.  Employees are encouraged to take time off to prevent burnout but realistically that isn't possible.

review_title: Family Teacher of a house of 6-8 boys
pros:
* Can feel like a big family
* BT Home Campus has everything all in one
* Amazing Benifits & great doctors
* No rent 
* Lots of opportunity to advance in company if you conform and fit in with the right people
cons:
* Off days are NEVER fully off
* Actually 24/7 job
* Lack of ACTUAL job support (frequently need help with BT youth situations, appts., etc. , but no extra assistance is available)
* Always stretched thin because of enormity of job duties
* BT oftenputs BT youth needs above needs of employee and employee's family; safety, emotional health, and concerns

pros: Good training program when you start. Pay is decent. Gas reimbursement. Insurance is about the same as any other company. Hi deductible and a low deductible ( nothing new)
cons: It feels as though it’s a sales job. Recruiting parents to take a parenting class can be challenging. Upper management may be a bit divided and they each seem to have their own agenda rather that work together as a team and towards the ultimate goal which is helping people.

pros: Health insurance is good.  No copays for office visits within the system. Many free generic medications available at the pharmacy. Coworkers are generally nice and are together in shared suffering
cons: Poor communication from administration.  Many have suffered at administrators capricious behaviors.  Contract changes, pay changes, schedule changes, staffing changes made on a whim with no warning.  Plan to have 4-5 different bosses that chime in at different times to remind you they are in charge of you. Lots and lots of turnover happening. Administration likes to use threats as management style.  CEO turns a blind eye.  Minimal opportunities for advancement.  New ideas are not encouraged or welcomed.  Information is hoarded among a few administrators to protect their jobs and standing.

pros: The staff is really passionate about the youth in their care, and the behavior model really does seem to work with  youth. I have personally seen youth change over periods of time into individuals that would have been unimaginable upon first meeting them. Overall the change you see is amazing!
cons: The hierarchy appears to be super rigid and not keen to taking suggestions. I've seen supervisors and Directors become defensive when it was not necessary. Conversation and addressing the concerns would have been a better option.

pros: Boys Town provides an overall experience helping children and families. Staff are dedicated to putting children's services and needs first. Boys Town also provides you with a lot of information to start doing your job.
cons: Not much room to move up the company ladder. There is a lot of stress when it comes to being an employee working with youth and families. There are a lot of times that I feel that management was not empathetic to the situation that one was in.

review_title: Great researchers, success is up to you and luck
pros: An amazing group of researchers.  A collaborative feel and great connections to the auditory field.  You could not find better.
cons: Saw very mixed outcomes depending on the supervisor.  Some were great and launched careers.  Others completely ended careers that had high potential.  Ask where former employees have gone, find out why those that left the field did so.

pros: Good benefits, fairly consistent schedule
cons: Performance reviews were unfairly conducted, no advancement if you disagreed with management on anything, no support from supervisors when dealing with difficult situations.

pros: Best part is knowing you are helping kids change their life. You get to provide a family environment for kids who nasty have never experienced one. There is so much support offered to the kids.
cons: Lack off support from management, bad gossiping that occurs, unprofessional like behavior from management. At times very stressful when you reach out for help and receive little or no support.

pros: Boys Town is a family oriented organization with exceptional benefits. I have been a Boys Town employee for almost 10 years and plan to work here for many more. My coworkers are fun, team oriented individuals who are all here for the mission. We all play a part in saving children and healing families, and it is very gratifying to see and hear the many success stories. No matter what position employees work in, we all have the youth in mind and play a part in bettering their lives.
cons: Nothing that I can think of.

pros: Upper management is super helpful and have your back. Co-workers are willing to help cover cases for vacation time. The pay is good for a recent graduate.
cons: Federal regulations has forced Boys Town to move their consultants from salary to hourly. They're cracking down on overtime which in this field of work you can expect to work a lot of overtime with client time, meetings, court, and paper work.

pros: If you have a passion for helping at risk youth and families within your community Boys Town is the place you want to be!  Coworkers are like family, teamwork is encouraged, and they invest in training.
cons: Like any nonprofit work with the at risk population, it can be stressful.  Resilience and self-care are important skills to have to prevent burnout.

job_title: Family Consultant in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Helping families learn parenting skills and become successful.  Seeings or talking to families or youth months or years later and seeing how far they've come along.
cons: This position has a lot of turn over.  People want to help others, but don't realize how demanding the job is emotionally and physically.  Hours are not typical, but at the same time you do get to make your own schedule.  Have to work till 10pm, but don't start working until 2 or 3pm.

review_title: Boys Town is a great employer.
pros: Boys Town helps thousands of children and families across the nation.  We have great employees that love helping children.   The dedication of the staff is outstanding.  Boys Town operations are managed well and are efficient.  It is a very family friendly organization.
cons: The job never seems to be finished as there is always more children that need Boys Town's help.

pros: Great organization with a mission that is easy to get behind and support.  The benefits are good and a lot of talented employees who really support the mission.  Lots of opportunities for growth.
cons: A bit slow to change and move to new technologies or trends.  Non-profit salaries can be below median, but benefits really help to balance it out.

job_title: Specialty Clinic Staff Nurse in Omaha, NE
pros: Great health insurance.  Pharmacy benefits are awesome.  PTO and sick time are good.  A lot of generic medications don't cost after insurance.  Saves a lot of money.
cons: Management is very politically correct.  No support for staff.  Pt/client is always right.  There is never 2 sides to a story, only the pts

review_title: Great place to work, even through growing pains

pros: You get a lot of case management experience, get to help out families in need.
cons: The company recently went hourly which makes it difficult to achieve your hours when families cancel their appointments. You also have to utilize your own car and are required to have a higher car insurance policy that you pay for on your own. Your schedule is all over the place. It often times takes 14 hours to complete 8 hours because you have gaps in between. Your schedule revolves around your families schedule.

job_title: Youth Care Worker in Brooklyn, NY
pros: I enjoyed my boss. Had great relationships with youth.
cons: Not traditional corporate culture. Everything is based on friends rather than your actual qualifications. No breaks during 10hr shifts. Work duties are unrealistic and always understaffed. Working with kids with severe behavioral and mental heath issues.

job_title: Behavioral Health Technician III in Omaha, NE
pros: The Heath benefits can't be matched. Basically no additional costs outside of your premium if you go to a boystown clinic/hospital.
cons:
Everything else. You will be demoralized my management and children. You will be physically unsafe, and your mental health will suffer. You are a robot that will be programmed to operate "the Boys town way". Keep your ideas and opinions to yourself or you will find yourself looking for a new job (which is actually the best thing management will ever do for you).

There are very few places to work in which you would be worse off.

review_title: Not as great as they portray it

job_title: In- Home Family Service Consultant in Omaha, NE

review_title: Great Organization with a Great Mission

pros: People are great, benefits are amazing. Also, many untold rewards when serving the youth and families that are from all parts of this country.

review_title: disappointing, not the job that was described at the interview

pros: Gratifying to help troubled youth

pros: Boys Town is truly interested in enhancing staff members strengths, and promoting upward mobility.  The behavioral model really works with families, and is easy to teach/understand.  Our benefits are really good, too.

job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Boys Town, NE

cons: Management, leadership, unappreciative, disrespectful, childish behavior, clueless administrators. When they give you your job description they neglect to tell you that you'll be written up for not doing the duties that aren't in said description.

review_title: Great feeling getting to help children, but high turn over rate.
job_title: Behavioral Health Technician III in Omaha, NE
pros: Feeling like you can make a difference in the lives of young children.
cons: Management treated staff like a number. There is 95% turn over rate for staff because they do not have proper training and are not paid well for what they have to deal with. Often times there were not enough people working on a shift. Dangerous situations where children are harmful to themselves and or others did not seem to get taken care of in a very professional manner. There were times that nurses were not available for heath situations. The job seems very impersonal to the children because the staff is required to use particular wording when speaking the children as the children are a on a motivational point card system. The negative aspect about that system is that the children easily learn it and are able to manipulate the system. A person can not be too empathetic when working with a point system and these children need more than a point system to fix their behaviors. Once these children go back into the real world situations, they do not seem prepared because they became so accustomed to the point system and structure.
